awd_titl_txt: RUI: Adult neurogenesis: Contributions from the innate immune system
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the role that the immune system plays in the production of new cells (neurons) in the adult brain.  Adult crayfish are used for this research because the cell populations that produce new neurons are much easier to study and manipulate than in other animals commonly used for this type of research. Unlike neural stem cells in other animals such as mice, the population of cells that directly produces new neurons in adult brains do not self-renew; rather, this population appears to be replenished by cells coming from some other source in the body. Previous data indicate that the immune system provides these precursor cells to the adult crayfish brain. The goal of this proposal is to build on this previous research to definitively identify how the immune system contributes to the generation of adult-born neurons. The experiments are designed to test three hypotheses. The first aim examines the hypothesis that circulating blood/immune cells (hemocytes) interact with specific physical locations in the crayfish brain (neurogenic niches), that cause these cells to remain and produce descendants that differentiate into neurons. The second aim examines the hypothesis that hemocytes are chemically attracted to the neurogenic niches by specific molecules. The third aim examines the hypothesis that the nervous system regulates the production of the neural precursors by the immune system via the release of a chemical (serotonin) that biochemically modulates the fate of immune system cells. By clearly identifying these cellular and molecular influences, these studies will contribute to fundamental knowledge about how stem cells enable the production of new neurons in adult brains. This work also contributes to society through training undergraduates in stem cell research, and educating the general public about the value of non-mammalian biological research and the potential for life-long plasticity in the nervous system.

In this project, GFP-positive (GFP+) hemocytes originating in transgenic crayfish will be adoptively transferred to recipient non-transgenic animals, and their target organs and differentiated properties will be determined. In addition, GFP+ cells extracted from different regions of the immune system in transgenic crayfish will be used in adoptive transfers to define the tissue origins of cells that are competent to produce adult-born neurons. These studies will also identify local guidance cues that attract hemocytes to the neurogenic niche using in vitro cell migration assays, as well as in situ nucleic acid hybridization and immunocytochemistry to locate candidate molecules that have been identified by transcriptome analyses. Finally, the coordinated regulation of the innate immune system and adult neurogenesis by a 5-HT-activated cytokine (astakine 1; AST1) pathway will be tested. Differential expression and localization of AST1 in niche, brain and immune tissues will be assessed after altering 5-HT levels. By testing the hypothesis that cells originating in the innate immune system produce adult-born neurons, these studies challenge the canonical view that the ectodermal origins of embryonic neural tissues are the sole source of neurons in the adult brain.

por.por_cntn:
Decapod crustaceans (e.g., lobsters, crayfish), like mammals, retain the ability to make new brain neurons throughout life. However, unlike in mammalian species in which neural stem cells undergo long-term self-renewal, crayfish appear to lack these self-sustaining cells. Instead, hemocytes (blood cells) originating in the immune system give rise to the neural precursor cells responsible for adult neurogenesis, which are housed in a neurogenic niche located on the dorsal surface of the brain. During this award, our research has focused on four related goals that address fundamental questions about adult neurogenesis, using the red swamp crayfish Procambarus clarkii as the experimental model: (1) Identifying the type of hemocyte that is responsible for generating the neural precursor cells; (2) Defining local cues that influence the attraction of hemocytes to the niche; (3) Characterizing and localizing molecular markers of the neural precursor cell lineage; (4) Examining the serotonin-astakine pathway as a link between the immune and nervous systems. Figure 1 illustrates our current model of adult neurogenesis, which incorporates many of the critical results summarized below.

Three distinct types of hemocytes (hyaline, semi-granular and granular) have been defined in crayfish, based on qualitative and quantitative morphological criteria such as cell size, ratio of nuclear area to whole cell area (nucleocytoplasmic, or NC, ratio), presence of granules, and presence of pseudopodia. For example, hyaline cells are characterized by their relatively small cell size and spherical shape, high NC ratio (>0.50), and lack of cytoplasmic granules. Data derived from several different experimental approaches indicate that the hyaline cells are the prime neural precursor cell candidates. In addition, these are the only hemocyte type that proliferates in vivo and in vitro, and therefore the only blood cell type that takes up proliferation markers (e.g., BrdU and EdU).  In vivo longitudinal studies of EdU-labeled hemocytes have also shown, however, that the hyaline cells can give rise to semi-granular and granular hemocytes through gradual developmental changes that have been assessed with a variety of morphological measures. The hyaline cells therefore appear to function as stem-type cells, in spite of the fact that they do not undergo long-term self-renewal.

Our work has also used in situ hybridization and immunocytochemistry to study embryonic expression patterns of a suite of key developmental genes, including three SoxB group transcription factors, two achaete-scute homologs, a Snail family member, the differentiation determinants Prospero and Brain tumor, and the neuron marker Elav. Initial studies in crayfish embryos demonstrated that cell-type expression patterns have notable similarities to insects and branchiopod crustaceans, lending further support to the homology of hexapod-crustacean neuroblasts and their cell lineages. These techniques were then used to characterize molecular subregions and cell types in the neurogenic systems in the adult crayfish brain, demonstrating that cells in the neural precursor lineage express appropriate developmental markers during their migration and differentiation. 

Finally, experiments have tested the roles of the nervous system molecule serotonin and astakine-1, a cytokine released by the immune system, in adult neurogenesis. Our results demonstrate that altering the release of hemocytes from the immune system by adjusting astakine-1 levels also alters the timing of appearance of labeled cells in the neurogenic niche housing the neural precursor cells. This finding further supports the proposal that the immune system is responsible for replenishing the neural progenitor population in the niche, and also indicates that the specific timing of hemocyte incorporation into the niche is highly modifiable and prone to physiological and environmental influences that alter astakine-1 levels. Serotonin influences these processes by regulating astakine-1 expression, the attraction of hemocytes to the niche, and the speed of the cell cycle at stages in the neural precursor lineage.

Overall, our studies demonstrate that the immune and nervous systems both contribute in critical ways to adult neurogenesis in crayfish, by demonstrating that hyaline hemocytes are the probable neural precursor cells, and that  serotonin and astakine 1 regulate both immune function and adult neurogenesis. In this way, molecules released from the immune and nervous systems coordinate and control key processes involved in adult neurogenesis.

This award supported the work and training of 22 undergraduates enrolled at Wellesley College, a liberal arts college for women, as well as 2 postdoctoral fellows. The research summarized above provided opportunities for training and mentoring undergraduates from all backgrounds and ethnicities, with the primary goal of increasing retention of students in STEM fields who would traditionally be vulnerable to dropping out of the sciences. Lab members also have contributed to outreach efforts at local high schools and to lifelong learning programs for adults. 

Research has been disseminated primarily through publication in peer-reviewed journals and presentations by lab members at conferences and by invitation.
